statement: Two circles \( \mathcal{O}_1 \) and \( \mathcal{O}_2 \) intersect at \( M \) and \( N \). Let \( \ell \) be their common tangent that is closer to \( M \) than to \( N \), touching \( \mathcal{O}_1 \) at \( A \) and \( \mathcal{O}_2 \) at \( B \). The line through \( M \) parallel to \( \ell \) meets \( \mathcal{O}_1 \) again at \( C \) and \( \mathcal{O}_2 \) again at \( D \). Let the lines \( CA \) and \( DB \) meet at \( E \); let the lines \( AN \) and \( CD \) meet at \( P \); let the lines \( BN \) and \( CD \) meet at \( Q \). Prove that \( EP = EQ \).

Let \( a, b, c \) be positive real numbers with \( abc = 1 \). Prove that
\[ \left(a - 1 + \frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b - 1 + \frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c - 1 + \frac{1}{a}\right) \leq 1. \]

Let \( n \geq 2 \) be a positive integer and let \( \lambda \) be a positive real number. Initially, \( n \) fleas stand on a horizontal line, not all at the same point. A move is defined as follows: choose any two fleas at points \( A \) and \( B \) with \( A \) to the left of \( B \), and let the flea at \( A \) jump to a point \( C \) to the right of \( B \) such that \( \frac{BC}{AB} = \lambda \). For each value of \( n \), determine all values of \( \lambda \) for which, for any point \( M \) on the line and any initial positions of the \( n \) fleas, there exists a finite sequence of moves that transports all the fleas to positions to the right of \( M \).

A magician has 100 cards numbered 1 to 100. He distributes them into three boxes — red, white, and blue — each containing at least one card. An audience member selects two of the boxes, chooses one card from each, and announces the sum of the two numbers. From this sum, the magician identifies the box from which no card was chosen. How many ways are there to distribute the cards into the boxes so that the trick always works?
Does there exist a positive integer \( n \) having exactly 2000 prime divisors such that \( 2^n + 1 \) is divisible by \( n \)?

Let \( A_1A_2A_3 \) be an acute-angled triangle with altitudes \( A_1H_1, A_2H_2, A_3H_3 \). The incircle touches the sides \( A_2A_3, A_3A_1, A_1A_2 \) at \( T_1, T_2, T_3 \), respectively. Let \( L_1, L_2, L_3 \) be the reflections of the lines \( H_2H_3, H_3H_1, H_1H_2 \) in the lines \( T_2T_3, T_3T_1, T_1T_2 \), respectively. Prove that the lines \( L_1, L_2, L_3 \) determine a triangle whose vertices lie on the incircle of \( A_1A_2A_3 \).
